title: How to Make Saffron Rice

steps.headline: Wash off the rice.
steps.description: Get out a strainer, and pour the rice in it. Run it under water for a few minutes, moving the rice around with your hand to make sure it gets rinsed. Shake off the excess water.

steps.headline: Add all the ingredients to a medium pan.
steps.description: Pour in the cup of rice you just rinsed, the 2 cups of chicken stock, the tablespoon of butter (if you're using it), the 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and the pinch of saffron. Give it a gentle stir to incorporate the ingredients.

steps.headline: Bring it to a boil.
steps.description: Turn the heat on high to bring the pot to a boil. Once it's boiling, turn the heat down to low. let it simmer for about 20 minutes. When you lift the lid, make sure the rice has absorbed all the stock.

steps.headline: Serve the rice.
steps.description: Use a fork to fluff up the rice. Scoop the rice onto bowls or plates and serve. This dish works best as a side dish.

methods.name: Making Saffron Rice With Optional Peas and Cashews

steps.headline: Heat a saucepan.
steps.description: Place a saucepan on the stove. Turn the burner on to medium heat, and let the saucepan get warm.

steps.headline: Add the spices.
steps.description: Put the tablespoon of cumin and 1/4 teaspoon of saffron in the dry pan. Stir them around to make sure they don't stick or burn. Heat the seasonings for about 2 minutes to toast them. If you prefer, you can also saute the rice first. Add the optional oil to the pan over medium heat. Put the rice in, and let it cook for a few minutes. Add the spices (cumin, saffron, and garam masala) and let them cook a few minutes, too. If you're using cashews, add them when you add the spices. Wait a few minutes, and add the peas, if you want to use them. Let them cook for a minute.

steps.headline: Add the rice and liquid.
steps.description: Pour the 1 3/4 cup of liquid into the pan. Next, add in the cup of rice. If you've already toasted the rice, just add in the liquid. Let the mixture come to a boil over high heat with a lid. You can use water, but stock will add more flavor. The salt is up to you. You can add it if you prefer saltier foods.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat and let it simmer.
steps.description: Once the pot boils, turn the burner to low. Keep the pot covered. Let the rice simmer for about 15 minutes. Once 15 minutes is up, take it off the stove, and let it rest, covered, for 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Place the 3/4 teaspoon of saffron in a small bowl.
steps.description: The bowl should be heat proof. Add the two tablespoons of boiling water very carefully. Let it sit for a few minutes.

steps.headline: Fry the almonds.
steps.description: Heat the 1/3 cup of olive oil in a pot over medium-high heat. When the oil is hot (it should shimmer), add the almonds. Let them cook for about 3 minutes. They should be golden brown when they are done. Stir them often so they don't burn. Move them to paper towels or paper bag layers using a slotted spoon; let them sit to get rid of the excess oil. Leave the rest of the oil in the pan.

steps.headline: Add the onions.
steps.description: While the pan is still hot, put the 3 to 4 cups of chopped onions in. Let them cook until they are golden brown. It should take about 15 minutes. Make sure to stir them once in a while so they don't burn. Move half of them to another bowl.

steps.headline: Fry the rice.
steps.description: Pour the rice in with the onion, and let it cook. You'll only need to cook it about 2 minutes to let it get toasty before you boil it. Frying it creates more flavor. If you want to add the optional spices (the 4 green cardamom pods, 4 whole cloves, 1 1/2 inches of whole cassia bark, 1-2 bay leaves, and 1 star anise), now is the time to do it. Add it just before the rice, and let it cook for a few minutes before adding the rice in.

steps.headline: Add the the other ingredients.
steps.description: Put in the 4 1/2 cups of water. Also, add in the saffron that's been sitting, as well as 1 1/2 teaspoons of salt and 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Don't add the extra onions, the currants, or the almonds yet.

steps.headline: Bring it to a boil.
steps.description: Turn the heat up high. Once the pot has boiled, turn it down to low. Put a lid on it, and let it simmer. It should cook for about 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Serve the rice.
steps.description: After it has sat for 5 minutes off the heat with the lid still on it, it's ready to serve. Mix the extra onions with the currants and the onions. Scoop out the rice, and serve it with some of the onion-almond-currant mixture on top.

You'll only need to cook it about 2 minutes to let it get toasty before you boil it. Frying it creates more flavor. If you want to add the optional spices (the 4 green cardamom pods, 4 whole cloves, 1 1/2 inches of whole cassia bark, 1-2 bay leaves, and 1 star anise), now is the time to do it. Turn the heat up high. Once the pot has boiled, turn it down to low. Put a lid on it, and let it simmer. It should cook for about 20 minutes. Serve the rice.
